raw_text:
Row brewing over peer-to-peer ads
 
 Music download networks are proving popular not just with an audience of youngsters keen to take advantage of free music but with advertisers equally keen to reach out to a captive audience.
 
 The debate over the legitimacy of file-sharing networks rages on as the music industry continues its threats to close the services down for good. Meanwhile the millions of downloaders are proving both an advertiser's dream come true and a branding nightmare. Paul Myers, chief executive of Wippit - a peer to peer service which provides paid-for music downloads - believes it is time advertisers stopped providing 'oxygen' for companies that support illegal downloading. "You may be surprised to know that current advertisers on the most popular peer to peer service eDonkey who now steadfastly support copyright theft with real cash money include Nat West, Vodafone, O2, First Direct, NTL, and Renault," he said in an open letter to the British Phonographic Industry last month.
 
 He urged people to follow his lead and 'dump' brands associated with companies such as eDonkey. The BPI is equally quick to condemn established brands becoming bedfellows with peer to peer networks. 'Networks like eDonkey, Kazaa and Grokster facilitate illegal filesharing. The BPI strongly believes that any reputable company should look carefully at the support they are giving these networks through their advertising revenue," it said in a statement. "Illegal file-sharers steal millions of pounds worth of music through these services. We are sure that the companies advertising on them would not put up with theft on such a scale from their own businesses," it said. But the issue is often more complicated for advertisers, said Mark Mulligan, a music analyst with Jupiter Research. "This has been a problem for a long time, ever since the days of Napster," he told the BBC News website.
 
 The reality is that the millions of downloaders represent a very attractive audience. "Advertisers probably pay a lot less for putting ads here than on more respected sites and they are reaching the perfect target audience," he said. "If you put the legality issues aside, not to advertise here would mean missing out on a valuable audience," he added. Meanwhile companies contacted by the BBC News website insist that they were not directly aware of where their ads have been appearing. OneTel adverts were spotted on eDonkey this week and its response was typical. "We have investigated this matter and believe that one of our affiliate partners has placed this advert without our knowledge. It is not our policy to advertise through peer-to-peer networks," read a statement from the discount phone firm. It has requested the advert be removed immediately, said a spokeswoman. Similarly telecommunications firm NTL blames its media buying agency which places adverts with third party networks featuring thousands of sites. Since the matter was brought to its attention last month, the agency has strict instructions to make sure ads do not appear on such sites, a spokesman told the BBC News website.
 
 However Mr Mulligan was not entirely convinced by these explanations. While smaller brands might not necessarily be aware of where the money they allocate to online advertising actually ends, this is no excuse for well-known brands, he said. "I would be surprised if these brands didn't have the know-how to prevent this happening," he said. At the moment eDonkey is enjoying the benefits of having some very well-known faces advert on its network. "Many big brands have leveraged the opportunity, including perhaps two of the biggest brands in the world - Senator John Kerry and President George W. Bush," said chief executive Sam Yagan. There are some distinct advantages of advertising on such a network, he thinks. "Peer-to-peer clients offer big brands a unique opportunity to engage with their customers where they're most comfortable: at their desks interacting with their favourite digital media," he said.
llama3.2:1b:
Row brewing over peer-to-peer ads as music industry and advertisers disagree on legitimacy.

Music download networks are seen as attractive advertising options due to millions of downloads, but also pose a problem for the music industry which threatens to shut them down.

Advertisers support peer-to-peer services like eDonkey despite being linked to copyright theft, with Nat West, Vodafone, and Renault among those that have provided funding.

The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) condemns these links, while companies argue they are not aware of where their ads appear.

Mark Mulligan, a music analyst, suggests advertisers can reach target audiences without putting up with the issues, despite the problems for the industry.
llama3.2:3b: Advertisers support peer-to-peer networks despite music industry's threats to close them down, while the BPI condemns such partnerships due to copyright theft and financial loss for legitimate artists and labels. Companies like Nat West, Vodafone, and Renault advertise on eDonkey, sparking debate over the issue, with some arguing that advertisers should be aware of their ad placement and not support companies facilitating illegal file-sharing.
gemma2:2b: Music download networks like eDonkey attract both advertisers and copyright infringers. Advertisers value this large, captive audience but face legal concerns about supporting illegal sharing.  The debate centers on the morality of advertising on these platforms while companies like Wippit and OneTel try to disassociate themselves from such connections. Despite their efforts, some brands are still advertising on these networks, often with limited control over where their ads appear. This has led to a conflict between ethical considerations and market opportunities for advertisers.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Music download networks are gaining popularity among advertisers who are looking for high-traffic sites and have an audience of young people who want free music. Paul Myers, the CEO of Wippit, argues that advertisers should stop providing file-sharing services like eDonkey to close the platform down for good. This is because many companies support illegal downloading, which threatens the BPI's position as a guardian of intellectual property rights. Mark Mulligan, an analyst with Jupiter Research, believes that legal ad networks are more effective than peer-to-peer services in reaching their target audience and should be supported. The BBC News website has also reported on advertisers' willingness to advertise online advertising on peer-to-peer services like eDonkey.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Music download networks pose both an advertisement and legal challenge for the music industry as advertisers seek brand partnerships despite piracy. Peer-to-peer services like eDonkey provide advertising revenue but also attract illegal file-sharing users, leading to controversy over legitimate use of corporate funds. The issue is complex; while smaller brands might not be aware of their ads appearing on peer networks, major companies face an ethical dilemma with larger audiences benefiting from such ad placements.
qwen2.5:3b:
Row brewing over peer-to-peer ads

Music download networks have gained popularity among young listeners and advertisers alike due to the captive audience they provide. Despite ongoing debates about file-sharing services, millions of users continue to use them, making them attractive for brands seeking a targeted market. However, major music industry groups condemn these platforms for enabling copyright infringement, as illegal file sharing through networks like eDonkey results in substantial losses for the industry.

Advertisers find peer-to-peer (P2P) ads appealing due to their cost-effectiveness and targeting of younger audiences; however, they face backlash from established companies that view P2P platforms as sources of piracy. Companies such as Nat West, Vodafone, Renault, and First Direct have been criticized for associating with these networks. Despite this criticism, P2P services like eDonkey still attract major brands due to their unique targeting opportunities at users' preferred digital media platforms.

smollm:1.7b:
The debate over the legitimacy of file-sharing networks rages on as the music industry continues its threats to close the services down for good. Meanwhile, advertisers are proving both an advertiser's dream come true and a branding nightmare. Paul Myers, chief executive of Wippit - a peer-to-peer service which provides paid-for music downloads - believes it is time advertisers stopped providing 'oxygen' for companies that support illegal downloading. "You may be surprised to know that current advertisers on the most popular peer-to-peer service eDonkey who now steadfastly support copyright theft with real cash money include NatWest, Vodafone, O2, First Direct, NTL, and Renault," he said in an open letter to the British Phonographic Industry last month.
The debate over the legitimacy of file-sharing networks rages on as the music industry continues its threats to close the services down for good. Meanwhile, advertisers are proving both an advertiser's dream come true and a branding nightmare. Paul Myers, chief executive of Wippit - a peer-to-peer service which provides paid-for music downloads - believes it is time advertisers stopped providing 'oxygen' for companies that support illegal downloading. "You may be surprised to know that current advertisers on the most popular peer-to-peer service eDonkey who now steadfastly support copyright theft with real cash money include NatWest, Vodafone, O2, First Direct, NTL, and Renault," he said in an open letter to the British Phonographic Industry last month.
The reality is that the millions of downloaders represent a very attractive audience. "Advertisers probably are not directly aware of where their ads have been appearing," said onetelerialservices spokesperson. "It is not our policy to advertise through peer-to-peer networks." However, Mr Mulligan was not entirely convinced by these explanations. While smaller brands might not necessarily be aware of where the money they allocate to online advertising actually ends up, this is no excuse for well-known brands, he thought. "I would be surprised if these brands didn't have the know-how to prevent this happening," said chief executive of Wippit, Sam Yagan.
However, Mr Mulligan was not entirely convinced by these explanations. "Many big brands have leveraged the opportunity, for example Senator John Kerry and President George W. Bush," said chief executive of Wippit, Sam Yagan.
There are some distinct advantages of advertising on such a network, he thinks. While smaller brands might not necessarily be aware of where the money they allocate to online advertising actually ends up, this is no excuse for well-known brands, he thought. "I would be surprised if these brands didn't have the know-how to prevent this happening," said chief executive of Wippit, Sam Yagan.

Peer-to-peer (P2P) music download networks are gaining traction due to their success among artists, with advertisers increasingly using them for free ads while generating income through illegal activities like file-sharing. Paul Myers, CEO of Wippit, a P2P service, warns that current advertisers on eDonkey, which facilitates illegal downloads, support copyright theft with cash. He calls for companies to remove brands associated with eDonkey and suggestsdumping these brands. Meanwhile, the BPI strongly opposes this practice, emphasizing that any reputable company should review their advertising revenue with legal oversight. Mark Mulligan notes that while smaller brands may not be aware of their ads' target audience, larger brands like senators John Kerry and George W. Bush have already leveraged P2P networks for their media buying. Advertisers are likely paying more for ads in P2P than on respected networks due to the appealing nature of the audience. eDonkey is thriving as a result, while the BPI's stance remains firm against its practices.
tinyllama:1.1b: The debate over the legitimacy of file-sharing networks, which include peer-to-peer ads, continues to rage on as advertisers continue to support these networks. While many musicians and brands are supporting these services through their advertising revenues, some brand names, such as Nat West, Voya, O2, First Direct, NTL, and Renault, have been accused of supporting copyright theft with real-money payments. Advertisers on these networks are expected to follow suit and boycott illigal download sites by removing ads. However, despite this effort, big brands such as Senator John Kerry and President George W. Bush have leveraged the opportunity advertising on eDonkey's network. Peer-to-peer clients offer brand names like these a unique opportunity to engage with customers at their desks, where they are most comfortable.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The debate over the legality of peer-to-peer (P2P) networks and their potential impact on advertising revenue has been a contentious topic for years. In recent months, concerns have risen about the ease with which users can access free music files without paying for them. This issue has led to debates over whether it is appropriate for companies like eDonkey, which provides paid-for music downloads through its network, to support copyright infringement.

One of the most significant examples of this is the situation surrounding ad networks like eDonkey and its association with illegal file-sharing networks. These networks have gained significant popularity among users who wish to access free music files, without the need for payment. In response to concerns about copyright infringement, Paul Myers, the chief executive of Wippit, a peer-to-peer service that provides paid-for music downloads, believes it is time advertisers stopped providing "oxygen" for companies that support illegal downloading.

Advertisers have been aware of the legal issues surrounding P2P networks since the beginning, but there has been an increasing trend towards advertising on these networks. This has led to a number of companies, such as Nat West, Vodafone and O2, supporting copyright infringement through their advertising revenue. It is clear that the issue with these networks is not just that they facilitate illegal downloading, but also that they represent a very attractive audience. Mark Mulligan, a music analyst for Jupiter Research, believes that this has been a problem for advertisers for a long time. "This has been a problem for a long time, ever since the days of Napster," he told the BBC News website.

The reality is that millions of users on P2P networks represent a very attractive audience. This makes it difficult for companies to avoid advertising on these networks. OneTel, for instance, has responded to concerns about its adverts appearing on eDonkey by stating that they have investigated this matter and believe that one of their affiliate partners has placed the ad without their knowledge. However, it remains unclear whether the brands involved are aware of where the advertisements are appearing. Similarly, telecommunications firm NTL claims to have strict instructions from its media buying agency not to place ads on P2P networks featuring thousands of sites. Since the issue was brought to their attention last month, the agency has strict instructions to ensure that no ads appear on such sites.

Although smaller brands might not necessarily be aware of where the money they allocate to online advertising actually ends, this is no excuse for well-known brands, such as Senator John Kerry and President George W. Bush. It appears that these larger companies have the knowledge to prevent this happening, but there are still significant challenges in ensuring the legality of P2P networks and their potential impact on advertising revenue.
phi:2.7b: Peer-to-peer music download networks are popular among both music lovers and advertisers due to the captive audience. The debate over file sharing's legitimacy continues while many major brands still advertise on these networks, despite supporting illegal downloading. Some companies have banned their advertising from being featured on these services, but others believe that ignoring such a large audience would be detrimental to their business. Advertisers pay less for reaching this audience and the music industry has yet to come up with a way to effectively combat this issue.
orca-mini:3b: The music industry continues to debate the legitimacy of file-sharing networks, with advertisers caught in the middle. Some companies advertise on popular peer-to-peer networks and support illegal downloading by millions of downloaders. However, smaller brands might not necessarily be aware of where the money they allocate to online advertising actually ends. Well-known brands, on the other hand, should have the know-how to prevent this happening, according to Mark Mulligan. Advertisers pay less for advertising on peer-to-peer networks and reach a valuable audience, but some companies are still unclear where their ads appear.

The debate over file-sharing networks continues, with the music industry threatening to close such services down. Advertisers on peer-to-peer service eDonkey, which supports illegal downloading, include well-known brands like Nat West, Vodafone, O2, and Renault. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) condemns established brands associating with peer-to-peer networks that facilitate illegal filesharing. However, the millions of downloaders represent an attractive audience for advertisers, who can reach their target market more cost-effectively than on more respected sites. While some brands might not be aware of where their ads appear, this is no excuse for well-known brands to continue supporting such networks.

Paul Myers of Wippit criticizes advertisers for supporting illegal downloading and urges brands to withdraw from networks like eDonkey. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) also condemns companies advertising on such platforms, arguing they facilitate music piracy. Some companies claim ignorance about their ads appearing on file-sharing sites, blaming third-party agencies. Despite denials, experts believe major brands should be able to control ad placements. reference: The BPI strongly believes that any reputable company should look carefully at the support they are giving these networks through their advertising revenue," it said in a statement.We are sure that the companies advertising on them would not put up with theft on such a scale from their own businesses," it said.It has requested the advert be removed immediately, said a spokeswoman."I would be surprised if these brands didn't have the know-how to prevent this happening," he said.Music download networks are proving popular not just with an audience of youngsters keen to take advantage of free music but with advertisers equally keen to reach out to a captive audience."You may be surprised to know that current advertisers on the most popular peer to peer service eDonkey who now steadfastly support copyright theft with real cash money include Nat West, Vodafone, O2, First Direct, NTL, and Renault," he said in an open letter to the British Phonographic Industry last month.But the issue is often more complicated for advertisers, said Mark Mulligan, a music analyst with Jupiter Research.At the moment eDonkey is enjoying the benefits of having some very well-known faces advert on its network.While smaller brands might not necessarily be aware of where the money they allocate to online advertising actually ends, this is no excuse for well-known brands, he said.Paul Myers, chief executive of Wippit - a peer to peer service which provides paid-for music downloads - believes it is time advertisers stopped providing 'oxygen' for companies that support illegal downloading.Since the matter was brought to its attention last month, the agency has strict instructions to make sure ads do not appear on such sites, a spokesman told the BBC News website."Advertisers probably pay a lot less for putting ads here than on more respected sites and they are reaching the perfect target audience," he said.
